urn:contentItem:60DT-NNB1-JCSC-J02B-00000-00News in brief - 23 July 20202020-07-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:08ZLexisNexisNEWSNews in brief - 23 July 2020

NEW FCA HEAD SAYS MAINTAINING HIGH STANDARDS KEY TO COMPETITIVENESS POST-BREXIT Maintaining high regulatory standards is the best way to ensure the UK’s competitiveness as a dynamic financial centre, the incoming chief executive of the Financial Conduct Au... NEW FCA HEAD SAYS MAINTAINING HIGH STANDARDS KEY TO COMPETITIVENESS POST-BREXIT Maintaining high regulatory standards is the best way...

NEW FCA HEAD SAYS MAINTAINING HIGH STANDARDS KEY TO COMPETITIVENESS POST-BREXIT Maintaining high regulatory standards is the best way to ensure the UK’s competitiveness as a dynamic financial centre, the incoming chief executive of the Financial Conduct Au...

NEW FCA HEAD SAYS MAINTAINING HIGH STANDARDS KEY TO COMPETITIVENESS POST-BREXIT Maintaining high regulatory standards is the best way to ensure the UK’s competitiveness as a dynamic financial centre, the incoming chief executive of the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) Nikhil Rathi has said ( CityAM ). Speaking at a confirmation hearing with MPs on the Treasury Committee yesterday, Mr Rathi said having a formal competitiveness mandate for the FCA would risk complicating decision making. He added that it would be important for the UK to have the freedom to develop its own rules post-Brexit, while maintaining strong cooperation and trust between the FCA and its EU counterparts so that any rule changes do not unnecessarily jeopardise future market access ( Reuters ). Nikhil Rathi, who is due to take up his new position in October, said he also wants to see the FCA take a more “interventionist” approach to cracking down on financial promotions of risky investments ( The Times , £, p38). In addition, he warned City firms that director appointments could be blocked if companies fail to improve diversity by hiring more women and ethnic minority candidates in senior roles ( The Guardian , p31). IBFED REPORT CALLS FOR GLOBAL REGULATION TO ADAPT TO GROWING ROLE OF BIG TECH COMPANIES IN FINANCIAL SERVICES Policymakers and regulators worldwide should help shape an orderly modernisation and digitisation of the financial sector to address the opportunities and risks associated with big techs’ increasing role in financial services according to a new report by the International Banking Federation (IBFed) and global management consulting firm Oliver Wyman . The report makes three distinct sets of recommendations: revising measures within financial regulation, strengthening the policy response on themes that cut across industries, and extending finance-specific regulations to other industries where inconsistencies in regulation and enforcement have emerged. Lisa Quest, co-author of the report and the Head of Oliver Wyman’s Public Sector & Policy practice for the UK and Ireland, said: “In a few major markets, big techs’ unique scale and ecosystem model hold the potential to fundamentally change competitive dynamics…At the same time, there is also the potential for financial risks to arise outside the current regulatory perimeter.” Hannah Gurga, Managing Director, Digital Technology & Cyber, UK Finance, said: “Technology is transforming many aspects of our lives, including the way we choose to bank and manage our finances. Across the banking and finance sector, firms are investing in new technologies and partnering with fintech operators to develop products and services that better meet the needs of their customers. The entry of big tech into financial services creates new opportunities, but it also brings new risks. As we embark on this next market evolution, consideration is now needed as to how best to maintain the stability, resilience, and consumer protections that are so integral to the banking system.” NEWS IN BRIEF Stephen Pegge, Managing Director of Commercial Finance at UK Finance, has said updating state aid rules for the UK’s government-backed lending schemes could “make a real difference for some businesses” ( CityAM ). A report by MPs on the Public Accounts Committee has criticised the government’s failure to plan for the economic impact of a pandemic, warning that lessons had to be learned ahead of a potential second spike in infections ( BBC News ). A separate report by the Treasury Committee has warned that over a million people have been excluded from income support schemes designed to help people during the pandemic ( The Times , £, p42). The Governor of the Bank of England Andrew Bailey has appointed Laura Wallis as his private secretary, the first woman to fill the role. She will be responsible for overseeing the implementation of Mr Bailey’s policies with other Bank officials ( Daily Telegraph , £, p3). The EU is expected to warn that only several weeks remain to agree a trade deal with the UK if it is to be legally operational by the end of the year, after the latest round of talks failed to make tangible progress ( Financial Times , £, online only).

urn:contentItem:60F5-58G1-JCSC-J333-00000-00News in brief - 24 July 20202020-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:08ZLexisNexisNEWSNews in brief - 24 July 2020

BANK OF ENGLAND OFFICIAL CALLS FOR CHANGES TO ALLOW MORE EQUITY INVESTMENT Failure to attract long-term investment in private companies could risk “chronic” economic problems Alex Brazier, Financial Policy Committee (FPC) member, yesterday warned ( The Tel... BANK OF ENGLAND OFFICIAL CALLS FOR CHANGES TO ALLOW MORE EQUITY INVESTMENT Failure to attract long-term investment in private companies...

BANK OF ENGLAND OFFICIAL CALLS FOR CHANGES TO ALLOW MORE EQUITY INVESTMENT Failure to attract long-term investment in private companies could risk “chronic” economic problems Alex Brazier, Financial Policy Committee (FPC) member, yesterday warned ( The Tel...

BANK OF ENGLAND OFFICIAL CALLS FOR CHANGES TO ALLOW MORE EQUITY INVESTMENT Failure to attract long-term investment in private companies could risk “chronic” economic problems Alex Brazier, Financial Policy Committee (FPC) member, yesterday warned ( The Telegraph , B3, £). The Bank of England’s executive director for financial stability proposed that changes to tax rules and regulatory directives might be needed to encourage private investment to support companies through the economic fallout from coronavirus. Brazier argued that the ability for firms to raise investment through equity, rather than debt, could act as the crucial “additive” to ongoing support which should “continue to be injected” into the economy ( The Times , p42, £). These comments come as restructuring firm Begbies Traynor reported that over half a million businesses were in significant financial distress at the end of June ( The Times , p42, £). This was matched by doubts over the v-shaped recovery as a survey by GfK showed that consumer confidence had dropped in July, despite rising in May and June ( The Guardian , p31). In contrast, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) today reported that UK retail sales rose 13.9 per cent in June, returning to pre-pandemic levels ( Financial Times , £). However, the Bank’s own estimates predict 60 per cent of the largest businesses operating in the UK – accounting for around three quarters of turnover in the national economy – will face deficits in their cashflow this year ( The Times , p42). FACE COVERINGS MANDATORY IN BRANCHES FROM TODAY IN ENGLAND From today, people in England will be required to wear face coverings in bank branches, building societies and post offices ( BBC News , online). The wider changes now mean that coverings will also be required in enclosed public spaces including supermarkets, takeaways, shopping centres and transport hubs, as well as branches. However, whilst health experts have partially welcomed the changes, they have called for clearer guidance on ‘other’ enclosed public spaces – such as cinemas and museums – where face coverings will not be mandatory ( The Times , p10, £). Several major retailers have said they have no intention of policing the laws, which carry a penalty of a £100 fine ( The Telegraph , p1, £). Further information on the latest guidance on face coverings can be found here . NEWS IN BRIEF The Social Market Foundation has proposed radical plans to introduce a property capital gains tax, raising £629 billion in tax revenue. The think tank recommends that this revenue could be used to abolish stamp duty and introduce a first-time buyer incentive targeted at addressing generational inequality ( The Telegraph , B3, £). In parliament, the Treasury and BEIS committees are to launch new inquiries into how coronavirus has impacted the government’s green agenda and industrial strategy ( The Guardian , p33). The chancellor is preparing plans to announce a new UK infrastructure bank in the Autumn Budget ( Financial Times , £). Online trading companies have reported a rise in new customers during lockdown as small investors looked to take advantage of volatile markets ( The Guardian , p33). The U.S. Congressional hearing, which would have seen a showdown between the US government and the four big tech giants – Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google – is set to be postponed. This meeting would have been the culmination of a year’s investigation into the companies. A new date is yet to be confirmed ( Reuters ).

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X58-V1J1-JD3N-51B9-00000-00News in call for curbs on big tech2019-09-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:08ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 1News in call for curbs on big techANDREW WHITE, ASSOCIATE EDITOR, EXCLUSIVE

News Corp Australia has accused the tech giants of being the biggest single cause of damage to Australian media and called for measures that would prevent companies such as Google and Facebook from using content and data unless they signed up to a code of conduct backed by legislation.

News Corp Australasia executive chairman Michael Miller says that without swift measures to legislate reforms, more jobs in media will be lost and communities will lose valuable sources of information.

Writing in The Australian on Monday, Mr Miller says the pain is particularly stark for independent publishers and that the technology platforms have tried to frustrate media companies building subscription services to fund their journalism rather than giving it away or relying on advertising.

He calls for swift action to legislate recommendations from the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission inquiry into digital platforms amid an intensified lobbying campaign from the tech giants to block regulation of their industry.

The report, released in July, made 23 recommendations and found a need to address the imbalance between traditional media and technology companies such as Facebook and Google. The federal government has backed the report and said it would respond to the recommendations by the end of the year.

"We should be clear from the outset: no one has damaged journalism and Australians' ability to receive trusted, reliable information more than the big tech platforms," Mr Miller says.

"Their extraordinary profits are based on their unfair commercial exploitation of other people's content - and powerful legislative changes are needed to correct this imbalance." In a submission to Treasury, News Corp Australia backed a recommendation for the ACCC to set up a digital branch to monitor potentially unfair and anti-competitive practices and enforce competition and consumer issues.

The submission said Google and Facebook had become "unavoidable business partners", but oversight was needed of how their algorithms ranked and distributed news content and advertising to consumers.

News also backed a new code of conduct to govern relations between news media and the digital platforms. But it said the code should be backed by legislation and enforced by the ACCC because of its competition expertise, rather than the Australian Communications and Media Authority, as proposed in the final report.

Mr Miller says the government should legislate minimum standards, prohibit anti-competitive or discriminatory practices and set out real consequences for breaches.

Platforms would be banned from using any publisher's content and from collecting any data generated from it unless all publishers had negotiated agreements. News also wants an inquiry into the supply of ad tech services, a market that it says is "opaque by design" and dominated by Google and Facebook.

MEDIA P23

urn:contentItem:5X5C-S7N1-JD3N-51DM-00000-00News in call for curbs on big tech2019-09-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:08ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 1News in call for curbs on big techANDREW WHITE ASSOCIATE EDITOR

News Corp Australia has accused the tech giants of being the biggest single cause of damage to Australian media and called for measures that would prevent companies such as Google and Facebook from using content and data unless they signed up to a code of conduct backed by legislation.

News Corp Australasia executive chairman Michael Miller says that without swift measures to legislate reforms, more jobs in media will be lost and communities will lose valuable sources of information.

Writing in The Australian on Monday, Mr Miller says the pain is particularly stark for independent publishers and that the technology platforms have tried to frustrate media companies building subscription services to fund their journalism rather than giving it away or relying on advertising.

He calls for swift action to legislate recommendations from the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission inquiry into digital platforms amid an intensified lobbying campaign from the tech giants to block regulation of their industry.

The report, released in July, made 23 recommendations and found a need to address the -imbalance between traditional media and technology companies such as Facebook and Google. The federal government has backed the report and said it would respond to the recommendations by the end of the year.

"We should be clear from the outset: no one has damaged journalism and Australians' ability to receive trusted, reliable information more than the big tech platforms," Mr Miller says.

"Their extraordinary profits are based on their unfair commercial exploitation of other people's content - and powerful legislative changes are needed to correct this imbalance." In a submission to Treasury, News Corp Australia, publisher of The Australian, backed a recommendation for the ACCC to set up a digital branch to monitor potentially unfair and anti-competitive practices and enforce competition and consumer issues.

The submission said Google and Facebook had become "unavoidable business partners", but oversight was needed of how their algorithms ranked and distributed news content and -advertising to consumers.

News also backed a new code of conduct to govern relations between news media and the digital platforms.

But it said the code should be backed by legislation and -enforced by the ACCC because of its competition expertise, rather than the Australian Communications and Media Authority, as proposed in the final report.

Mr Miller says the government should legislate minimum standards, prohibit anti-competitive or discriminatory practices and set out real consequences for breaches.

Platforms would be banned from using any publisher's content and from collecting any data generated from it unless all publishers had negotiated agreements. News also wants an inquiry into the supply of ad tech services, a market that it says is "opaque by design" and dominated by Google and Facebook.

MEDIA P23

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y7K-7301-F03R-N0WN-00000-00News industry trade group wants to cut Big Tech's content safety net2020-02-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:08ZLexisNexisNews industry trade group wants to cut Big Tech's content safety netSara Fischer

Feb 18, 2020( Axios: https://link.axios.com/join/am-signup?source=aci Delivered by Newstex) The News Media Alliance, a trade group which represents thousands of U.S. newspapers, plans to propose limits to a rule that, to-date, has helped Big Tech companies dodge responsibility for the content people upload to their platforms.The big picture: The 24-year-old provision, Section 230[1] of the 1996 Communications Decency Act, allows tech companies like Google, Facebook and Twitter to host user-generated content on their platforms without being liable for what it contains. The rule has paved the way for the modern internet economy, but has also been blamed for giving tech companies little incentive to police nefarious content or false information on their platforms.

According to a written testimony provided to Axios, NMA will tell parties on Wednesday at the Justice Department's upcoming workshop on Section 230 that policymakers should limit the safe harbor exemption within the law that protects tech platforms from being sued for the content that other people post on its site. "[W]e should start by limiting the exemption for just the very largest companies who both derive the most benefits from Section 230 and have the greatest capacities to take legal responsibility for their commercial decisions around content and reach," the testimony says.NMA CEO David Chavern will be testifying. The big picture: U.S. Attorney General William Barr said last month that the DOJ was looking into the law because 'many are concerned that Section 230 immunity has been extended far beyond what Congress originally intended,' per Reuters[2]. Go deeper: National newspapers thrive while local outlets struggle to survive[3] [ 1]: https://www.axios.com/social-media-immunity-section-230-f15ac071-32e9-4e33-81e6-4c7ebadaea5e.html [ 2]:   https://www.reuters.com/article/us-internet-regulation-justice/u-s-justice-dept-plans-to-hold-meeting-to-discuss-tech-industry-liability-sources-idUSKBN1ZN2E5 [ 3]:   https://www.axios.com/newspapers-national-local-news-divide-bankruptcy-576fe4c0-70e4-4bb2-9cba-28841552efe0.html

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5F15-7F71-JCP2-524J-00000-00Newsmakers of the year: 20142014-12-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:08ZLexisNexisNEWSNewsmakers of the year: 2014LIBN Staff

As another year comes to a close, we take a look back at the people, companies and stories that have shaped the Long Island business community in 2014.

Though local businesses continue to face challenges – such as the high costs of living and doing business here – the region heads into next year with renewed optimism. Several major real estate deals in 2014 point to reinvigorated confidence in the economy. Employment numbers are up, energy prices are down, interest rates remain low and the business lending environment has loosened – which all point to continued improvement in 2015. The year in finance: Growth at a high price By Claude Solnik

It was the year that big banks went to court, Long Island banks went to Manhattan and credit unions went to college.

But wherever they went, in 2014, everyone in the finance realm – on Long Island and nationally – meant business.

Middling mortgages, big business push

Banks began 2014 hoping interest rates would finally start rising, leading to higher loan rates that let them charge borrowers more and pay depositors more. Instead, bankers spent the entire year battling what many called “challenging” conditions, in the form of continued low rates.

The Federal Reserve, in fact, kept rates near historic lows – good news for borrowers but not for banks. As the end of the year approached, rates on 30-year fixed mortgages dipped below 4 percent.

One side effect: An uptick in refinancing, as some mortgage holders jumped on low rates to shift to shorter-term mortgages.

But rather than rely on shaky mortgage businesses, many banks looked to grow their business lending in 2014. If mortgages wouldn’t pay off via high rates, perhaps business loans would boost profits.

Lake Success-based Astoria Bank (which in 2014 officially changed its name from Astoria Federal Savings and Loan Association) hired more business bankers, and it wasn’t alone. Increased business-banking staffs set the tone across the industry – although many banks ultimately noted that business customers were generally too cautious to borrow, while increased efforts by credit unions to make commercial loans also hurt business lending at traditional banks.

Growing concerns

Despite giant leaps in mobile banking, 2014 did not mark the end of the brick-and-mortar branch, with many institutions opening new loan offices, in addition to traditional and mini-branches.

TD Bank, which manages regional operations out of its Melville office, rolled out several new branches, now totaling 58 on Long Island. Riverhead-based Suffolk Bancorp expanded west, while Bridgehampton-based Bridge Bancorp ended the year by acquiring Community National Bank – thereby becoming the latest Long Island bank to operate a Manhattan branch.

Astoria also opened a Manhattan branch this year, part of a new marketing campaign aimed at growing its Manhattan business on the backs of Long Island-based commuters.

Other institutions in growth mode this year: Bethpage Federal Credit Union, which opened its 30th branch in 2014, and Islandia-based Gold Coast Bancorp, which in December was reportedly eyeing its own Manhattan location.

The price of compliance

Banks and credit unions themselves weren’t the only things growing in 2014. Regulations also expanded, and so did the cost of compliance.

Islandia-based Empire National Bank, and many other institutions, added teams of new compliance officers, while some banks – including Westbury-based New York Community Bancorp – maneuvered to keep their reported assets below certain thresholds, to avoid additional regulations and compliance costs.

Some banks couldn’t avoid the high cost of compliance. Many big banks settled with regulators in 2014 over a wide range of abuses, including BNP Paribas and Bank of America, which settled with New York State regarding several improprieties and helping build a state surplus of more than $5 billion.

Also biting the compliance bullet: Morgan Stanley, the global financial services firm that paid $4 million to address federal charges that it allowed a customer to complete an unauthorized purchase of $525 million in Apple stock.

Speaking of financial settlements, the Bernie Madoff ball of string continued to unravel in 2014, with trustee Irving Picard collecting more than $10 billion on behalf of bilked investors.

Among the settlements approved by the U.S. Bankruptcy Court: A $62 million deal with developer Edward Blumenfeld and his family, who – while maintaining they were also victims of Madoff’s legendary Ponzi scheme – agreed to pay $32.75 million in cash to the Bernard Madoff investment Securities Customer Fund and up to another $29 million in funds they claimed were owed to them by the fund.

To breach his own

In addition to low rates and the high price of compliance, banks faced another major challenge in 2014: cybersecurity breaches at major retailers, generating massive costs to replace compromised debit and credit cards and upgrade technology.

Home Depot, Michael’s Stores, Staples and national retailer Bebe all suffered major hack attacks in 2014 (not to mention Sony, which took a major fiscal bath after hackers took private data hostage and forced the studio to cancel the Christmas Day release of its controversial comedy “The Interview”). Banks fought back, experimenting with new tech that makes fraud harder and ushering in a new era of payment technology.

Apple jumped into the fray with a new system that lets consumers pay at retail locations with their smartphones, while Target announced it would roll out readers for smart-chip-enabled credit cards at its 1,800-plus U.S. stores in 2015 – six months earlier than planned.

Private equity, M&A on the rise

Always worth monitoring is the amount of private equity being pumped into Long Island firms, and in 2014, more than a few private-equity concerns bought into Long Island businesses.

San Francisco-based Vector Capital reached a deal this year to buy Melville-based broadcast-graphics producer ChyronHego for $114 million. West Palm Beach, Fla.-based Palm Beach Capital took a stake in Farmingdale-based Harold Levinson Associates, a major regional distributor to convenience stores.

And there were multiple examples of Long Island-based private equity funds pouring money into private and publicly traded firms, including several high-tech startups. Codagenix, a biotech startup that grew out of Stony Brook University research, netted $100,000 from Accelerate Long Island and the Long Island Emerging Technologies Fund.

In addition to private-equity investments, many companies expanded in 2014 through mergers and acquisitions. Fueling the M&A activity was the large number of baby boomers retiring, with fewer and fewer passing the family business down to the next generation.

Healthcare firms in particular stayed busy mixing and matching. Kansas-based AlexaCare Health Solutions bought Farmingdale-based intravenous-therapy provider Advanced Care. Virginia-based medical-supply distributor Owen & Minor spent $207 million on Brentwood surgical products maker Medical Action Industries. And Melville-based healthcare products distributor Henry Schein acquired 60 percent of Massachusetts-based SmartPak, a provider of equine supplements.

Next page: The year in technology

RELATED: Big financial institutions on campus

The year in technology: Big deals abound By David Winzelberg

Consolidations and acquisitions marked Long Island’s technology sector this year, though regional tech interests were also boosted by assistance from government contracts, trade group advocacy and private benefactors.

A tightening national defense budget still provided demand for specialty electronic systems, helping to grow some of the area’s niche manufacturers and suppliers, while renewed investment in dotcoms was also a trend in 2014, as Internet-based businesses tried to capitalize on increasing online consumer spending.

LIFTS, launches and a Simons score

In January, the Long Island Forum for Technology opened a 25,000-square-foot high-tech Composite Prototyping Center in Plainview with an eye toward giving the region an edge in a growing manufacturing sector.

The state provided $15 million to fund the cutting-edge center, which helps develop a wide range of new products related to a high-tech manufacturing sector that is only now developing. LIFT’s new site gives firms access to a wide range of devices, such as 3-D printers, laser-cutters and autoclaves.

Also opening doors in 2014 was LaunchPad Long Island, the tech-biz startup incubator that originally launched in Mineola. This year, LaunchPad opened satellite facilities in Huntington and Stony Brook, and also announced plans to open a new office in Great Neck Plaza – a 7,600-square-foot space at 3 Grace Ave. that will accommodate up to 30 startup enterprises at monthly rents as low as $149 for a desk and $700 for a private office.

Speaking of economic boosts with a tech bent, philanthropists Jim and Marilyn Simons provided a $50 million gift in 2014 to create the Simons Center for Quantitative Biology at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory.

The center will unite experts across numerous disciplines – including applied mathematics, computer science, theoretical physics and engineering – to research illnesses such as cancer, autism, bipolar disorder and depression.

The year of the acquisition…

Bay Shore-based Air Industries Group acquired four companies this year, including Deer Park-based Woodbine Products and three Connecticut firms: AMK Technical Services, Electronic Connection Corp. and Eur-Pac Corp.

Woodbine, which specializes in chassis used to house aircraft electronics, will become part of Air Industries’ Welding Metallurgy Inc. subsidiary in Hauppauge.

AMK’s management and employees, including 30 welders that serve aerospace and industrial customers, came on board. Eur-Pac, which supplies assemblies and kits to the U.S. Department of Defense, will be operated as a separate and independent platform company of Air Industries Group.

Air Industries Group wasn’t the only company in a buying mood this year. Plainview-based Veeco Instruments acquired Solid State Equipment Holdings, a private company based in Horsham, Pa., for $150 million.

Veeco makes equipment used to produce LEDs, solar cells, electronics, hard drives and wireless chips. Veeco anticipates that Solid State, which makes processing equipment used to produce semiconductors and micro-electro-mechanical systems, will generate $65 million in sales in 2015 – a potentially strong boost for the firm’s earnings.

And Plainview-based Aeroflex Holding Corp., a maker of wireless communication parts and systems, was acquired by British communications giant Cobham in a deal valued at $1.46 billion.

Cobham employs more than 10,000 people on five continents, according to a company statement. It specializes in audio, video and data communications, including satellite communications, defense electronics, air-to-air refueling and other aviation services. Aeroflex employs about 2,600 people in 20 locations globally.

… and other big tech deals

Stony Brook-based Applied DNA Sciences obtained a two-year contract valued at $2.97 million from the Office of the Secretary of Defense on behalf of the Defense Logistics Agency.

That order followed a $975,000 contract that Applied DNA received in July from the Office of the Secretary of Defense, collectively giving it what its CEO James Hayward called a “significant revenue foundation. ”

The military already uses Applied DNA’s markings on microcircuits, but the firm said these additional projects demonstrate the use of its “authentication solutions for other high-risk commodities. ”

Another notable deal from Long Island’s tech scene involved Hauppauge-based electronics manufacturer Voxx International, which put its money where its eyes are. The company invested $3 million into Carnegie Mellon Robotics Institute startup EyeSee360, with Voxx officials stating the money would assist development of a new line of EyeSee360’s portable panoramic video cameras, including the 360Fly and 360MicroFly.

Voxx International and EyeSee360 debuted the 360Fly product line at the 2014 Consumer Electronics Show in January, following an exclusive distribution agreement between the companies.

Voxx also made a $3 million “strategic investment” in New York City-based EyeLock, an identity-authentication solutions provider that works with iris-based technologies. EyeLock officials said the capital infusion and improved distribution will improve market access for its Myris product, a USB-enable iris-identity authenticator with applications for home and office use.

Next page: The year in healthcare

RELATED: Big sigh of relief at BNL

The year in healthcare: If you thought Obamacare was scary... By Claude Solnik

Barack Obama campaigned for the White House on a platform that promised change, and in 2014, the second year of his second term, change came to the national healthcare system in a big way.

Although open enrollment actually began late in 2013, this was the year when the full effects of the Affordable Care Act’s online health insurance exchanges were felt – and when several individual mandates kicked in.

But for all its historic implications and industry-shifting gravitas, Obamacare was, arguably, only the second-biggest healthcare story of 2014. This was also the year Ebola came to America.

Slow to act

One irony of the ACA, at least in New York State, was that a system designed partially to help small businesses provide health insurance for employees struck out with business owners – although individual persons flocked to it, often lured by individual-enrollee government subsidies.

New health plans for nearly 1 million individual New Yorkers, obtained through the state’s online marketplace, took effect in 2014. But only 3,000 businesses across New York enrolled through the state’s online small-business marketplace, with fewer than 10,000 employees obtaining coverage.

The numbers were particularly low on Long Island: Just 584 workers in Nassau County and 804 workers in Suffolk County obtained insurance after their companies enrolled through the state’s Small Business Health Options Program.

Meanwhile, multiple Obamacare individual mandates kicked in this year, bringing penalties of $95 per uninsured adult and $47.50 per uninsured child – up to $285 per family or 1 percent of family income, whichever is greater.

Federal regulators, however, tapped the brakes on corporate mandates originally scheduled to take effect in 2014, giving companies extra time to get their insurance houses in order. In 2015, companies with 100 or more full-time employees will have to start offering insurance or risk paying fines – and many spent 2014 tabulating employee hours and otherwise planning Obamacare strategies. Outside consultants cashed in.

The year ended with the future of Obamacare in doubt. With Republicans set to control both the U.S. Senate and the U.S. House of Representatives in 2015, there’s already been quiet talk of repealing the divisive Affordable Care Act, or at least modifying it significantly.

Emergency landings

While Obamacare made plenty of headlines, it took a back seat for much of 2014 to the Ebola virus, which finally traveled from the African continent to the United States. Two people died, and several others – including one New York resident – were infected and quarantined.

Hospitals across the country changed protocols to prepare for the worst, including Long Island hospitals, which spent millions on staff training and new facilities in preparation for a potential epidemic.

While a feared Ebola epidemic has not yet materialized in the United States, the American healthcare system also spent time and money in 2014 preparing for different kinds of emergencies.

Urgent care centers cropped up almost as fast as coffee shops, sometimes filling prime retail spaces. Patients flocked to local centers, which offer rapid care for minor illnesses and injuries – often at a cheaper price than can be found in an emergency room.

To relieve the burden on their emergency departments, some hospitals even got into the urgent care center business. In October, the Great Neck-based North Shore-LIJ Health System announced a partnership with California-based urgent care center operator Access Clinical Partners to open 50 centers in the New York area over the next four years, to be branded as North Shore-LIJ-GoHealth Urgent Care.

Expansion teams

Aside from building new urgent care networks, hospitals took advantage of a slowly recovering construction industry in 2014 to enlarge their physical footprints. Stony Brook University Medical Center, for instance, pushed ahead with a new research facility and a new children’s hospital, both slated to open in 2016.

But growth wasn’t limited to physical construction. In many ways, 2014 was the year of the merger for Long Island healthcare, with regional healthcare enterprises snapping up – or being snapped up by – similar practices.

Rockville Centre-based Catholic Health Services of Long Island and Far Rockaway-based St. John’s Episcopal Hospital together acquired a 50 percent stake in Beacon Health Partners, a Westbury-based network of physicians. South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside acquired the assets of the Long Beach University Medical Center, which suffered terrific damage in 2012’s Hurricane Sandy, for $11.8 million. Numerous smaller practices and solo practitioners sought strength in numbers, joining up with larger healthcare systems – not only to compete, but to keep down compliance costs and other overhead.

And Melville-based medical supplier Henry Schein acquired stakes in smaller companies around the world, leading to an end-of-year buyback of up to $300 million worth of the publicly traded company’s shares.

The high cost of health

Healthcare inflation continued in 2014, with insurance rates rising sharply at year’s end – though not as sharply as insurers had hoped.

On average, insurance providers requested a 12.5 percent increase in individual premiums in 2015, according to the New York State Department of Finance Services. But the state granted average increases of only 5.7 percent.

New wonder drugs found their way to market, including a pill said to be capable of curing 90 percent of all cases of hepatitis C, which afflicts 3.2 million Americans. However, in many cases, the wonder drugs proved cost-prohibitive for the average patient; Sovaldi, the hepatitis C pill created by California-based Gilead Sciences, runs $1,000 a pop – or $84,000 for a full 12-week treatment.

Next page: The year in real estate

RELATED: North Shore-LIJ: The big get bigger

The year in real estate: Building momentum By David Winzelberg

Record low interest rates and a more favorable development climate helped propel the Long Island commercial real estate market forward in 2014.

Though sales and prices in the single-family housing market remained flat, the demand for rental housing spurred multifamily builders and several major mixed-use projects were advanced by municipalities, including the Ronkonkoma Hub, Heartland Town Center and Islip Pines. Among major developments breaking ground this year were the Piazza at Glen Cove and the Hamptons Business District at Gabreski Airport.

Large transactions, such as the $94 million sale of the Broadway Mall in Hicksville and the $66.2 million purchase of the Long Island Marriott in Uniondale, pointed to renewed confidence in the area’s economy.

More national and regional retailers landed a presence here in 2014. Quick Chek opened its first Long Island location in Lake Grove, the area’s first Chick-fil-A restaurant was approved for Port Jefferson Station, Bass Pro Shops is coming to Uniondale and Long Island’s first full-sized Stew Leonard’s store is on tap for East Farmingdale.

Brookhaven approves Ronkonkoma Hub zoning

The Brookhaven Town Board approved new zoning for a $475 million plan to remake some 50 acres around the Ronkonkoma Long Island Rail Road station.

The move makes way for the massive, mixed-use redevelopment that will add more than 300 rental apartments, as well as accompanying retail space to the neighborhood. East Setauket-based Tritec Realty is the town’s designated master developer for the Ronkonkoma Hub redevelopment, which is expected to create more than 1,000 direct construction jobs, more than 500 permanent jobs and almost 5,000 secondary jobs.

Dealertrack in deal for North Hills HQ

Lake Success-based Dealertrack Technologies announced it will expand to a yet-to-be-built 233,000-square-foot headquarters on 9 acres in North Hills, and promises to add more than 350 new jobs to the 500 or so employees it already has here.

The new environmentally friendly, LEED-certified building planned for 3400 New Hyde Park Road is about one mile from Dealertrack’s current Lake Success headquarters and should be ready in early 2016, according to a company statement. The site is vacant land owned by Castagna Realty, which also owns the Americana shopping center in Manhasset. The new building was designed by The Spector Group in Woodbury, and will be built by a partnership between Castagna and Tritec.

Huntington approves Seasons at Elwood zoning

After months of heated discussion and debate, the Town of Huntington voted 4-1 in August to approve a change of zone that makes way for a 256-residence, over-55 condominium development on 37 acres in East Northport.

Garden City-based Engel Burman Group had scaled back its plan to build the age-restricted housing development dubbed Seasons at Elwood after working out a compromise with town officials. Though the developer reduced the size of the project twice — from 482 to 360 to 256 residences — members of two civic groups continued to oppose it.

Smithtown green-lights proposed Sonic

The Town of Smithtown’s Board of Zoning and Appeals granted a special exception that paves the way for a new Sonic Drive-In restaurant in Nesconset.

The town had denied the application from Harrison, N.Y.-based Sonic franchisee Cinos in November 2012, but a state Supreme Court judge annulled that denial in March ruling that the Smithtown BZA had “improperly bowed to community pressure” in its determination.

Subsequent negotiations between representatives of the zoning board, the franchisee and land owner, Serota Properties, resulted in a settlement that calls for some changes in the originally proposed plan.

Ribbon cutting for Tritec’s New Village in Patchogue

Tritec Real Estate executives joined elected officials, business owners and local residents to cut the ribbon of its $108 million, mixed-use development in downtown Patchogue.

Called New Village, the project is built on a six-acre site on West Main Street between Havens and North Ocean avenues, and brings 291 new rental apartments above 15,000 square feet of ground-level retail space. New Village also adds 500 much-needed parking spaces, 293 of those underground.

Touted as a model of new urbanism and smart growth, New Village has won numerous awards for its redevelopment of a blighted property that once housed Swezey’s department store.

Mega-projects advanced in Islip

The Town of Islip advanced two major development projects this year.

In April, the Islip Town Board unanimously accepted the final environmental impact statement for the $4 billion Heartland Town Square development, which proposes to create 9,100 apartments, 1 million square feet of retail space and more than 3 million square feet of offices on 460 acres of former Pilgrim State Hospital land in Brentwood.

The first phase of the project, which still requires a change of zone and site-plan approval, would build 3,500 apartments.

Project developer David Wolkoff said the planned mix of rental apartments, shops, restaurants and offices will eventually generate about 23,000 permanent jobs, and at least 1,500 construction jobs annually throughout its build-out, which could easily eclipse 20 years.

Islip also approved a zoning change that will make way for Serota Properties to build a $300 million mixed-use development on 130 vacant acres in Holbrook.

Formerly zoned as industrial, the site at the northeast side of where Veterans Memorial Highway merges with Sunrise Highway is slated to have 350 residences, 1 million square feet of industrial/office space, 340,000 square feet of retail space, a hotel, multiscreen movie theater, multiple athletic fields and tennis courts, community center, a 12.7-acre “great lawn” with an outdoor stage and a 30,000-square-foot open-air marketplace to hold farmers markets and other events.

Next page: The year in government

RELATED: Taubman taps out

The year in government: Private-public partnerships By Jacqueline Birzon

Under Albany’s directive, there was some formidable expansion among Long Island’s businesses in 2014. State and local governments geared up their business-boosting incentives, doling out sweet deals to local manufacturers and creating potential landscapes for job retention throughout the region. With lucrative investments from state and regional economic development councils, Long Island was a top performer, proposing projects that will allow companies to spread their wings and invest throughout the region, hopefully at some of the smaller airports and colleges.

Cuomo makes 2014 the year of the startup

While introduced in 2013, Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s Start-Up New York initiative made waves at the turn of the new year. Cuomo launched an aggressive campaign touting New York’s new “open for business” slogan.

In January, businesses started forming private-public partnerships with colleges across Long Island as part of the 10-year, tax-free Start-Up NY program. The program offers space to qualifying businesses striking state-approved deals with local industrial development agencies and colleges.

But mid-rollout, the program fell flat on Long Island, despite television ads that portrayed a government eager to suspend taxes for new business as an investment in the future, allowing businesses to operate for 10 years near college campuses and other large-scale R&D facilities with no income tax, business, corporate, state or local taxes, sales and property taxes, or franchise fees.

But Long Island’s R&D facilities still plugged the program, with Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory marketing Start-Up NY’s benefits as a plus at Broad Hollow Bioscience Park, a state-approved site at Farmingdale State College. In October, the state approved six companies – including one expanding from Ohio – to take part in its Start-Up NY program through Stony Brook University, creating roughly 90 jobs in the region. In the first 11 months, 41 businesses in all signed on for the Start-Up NY program, which is expected to result in an investment of 1,750 jobs and $77 million.

Guided Interventions, a medical device company founded in 2011, expanded to Long Island from Ohio through a $300,000 investment, and created five new jobs after latching on to the initiative, while heart valve firm Polynova Cardiovascular added 17 new jobs and invested $314,000 into its Stony Brook tax-free site.

In December, Empire State Development awarded Long Island $81.9 million in the fourth round of the state’s regional economic development council awards, making Long Island a top performer among the state’s 10 regions. LIREDC’s proposal this year included 97 projects, including a $4.7 million investment in the Wyandanch Rising project to increase employment in the Suffolk hamlet of Wyandanch; $2.5 million for Adelphi University’s $15 million Nursing Innovation Lab and Training Center; and $1.5 million toward Hofstra University’s Science Math Technology Engineering Learning Center.

Other projects submitted in the fourth round sought funds for a storm-water mitigation project in Nassau County, a Center for Environmental Research and Coastal Oceans Monitoring at Molloy College and an Agriculture Capital Equipment Grant “Farmers for the Future” program.

Business meets politics at Long Island IDAs

While little changing of the guard occurred in Albany, Long Island’s local development agencies saw changes in leadership due to politics, messy district attorney investigations and attractive job opportunities in the private sector.

In March, Anthony Manetta stepped down from his post after two years as executive director of the Suffolk County Industrial Development Agency in exchange for a private-sector position, leaving the Suffolk IDA to embark on a dragged-out process of finding a suitable predecessor. But after the IDA’s favorite pick, ex-Babylon IDA CEO Robert Stricoff, fell through the cracks amid an investigation by Suffolk County District Attorney Thomas Spota’s office, IDA officials didn’t look very far for a second successor, who wound up being none other than Tony Catapano, its longtime second-in-command.

Despite changes in leadership, the IDA was able to realize several major deals, including convincing Hauppauge manufacturer A&Z Pharmaceutical, which had considered relocating out of state, to invest $28.6 million into a four-year expansion project in Suffolk County.

According to a report released in May, Long Island in 2012 provided the highest amount of tax exemptions of New York’s 10 regions, totaling $118 million. And while Long Island IDAs gave out the highest amount of tax exemptions in the state, the Island also added 54,975 jobs as a direct result of IDA-sponsored initiatives, which represented more than a quarter of the 214,102 IDA-related jobs created statewide.

Changing of the guard

Familiar faces remained in Albany, where Cuomo’s reign will continue for the next four years, along with democratic Comptroller Thomas DiNapoli and Attorney General Eric Schneiderman at the helm of the state’s financial and legal directives, respectively.

On Long Island, several key power players made the jump from the minors to the big leagues, including Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice’s election to U.S. Congress, replacing longtime Rep. Carolyn McCarthy on the Washington landscape. State Sen. Lee Zeldin’s rise to glory came at the cost of longtime democratic incumbent, Tim Bishop, losing the U.S. congressional seat he held for more than 10 years.

The 2014 midterm elections gave Islip Town Supervisor Tom Croci an opportunity to leave his Islip post for a seat in the state Senate, in a race where he crushed opponent Adrienne Esposito, an environmental activist who will continue her work on Long Island and possibly help clean up the 50,000 tons of contaminated construction debris illegally dumped in Islip’s Roberto Clemente Park.

RELATED: State to focus on growing LI exports, aviation

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W9H-1PB1-JBCN-40KJ-00000-00News Media Alliance pushes back;Publishers seek bigger slice of digital revenue2019-06-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:08ZLexisNexisAR NEWSPg. C7News Media Alliance pushes backPublishers seek bigger slice of digital revenueKate Ackley CQRoll Call

WASHINGTON — The News Media Alliance is scoring some legislative points against the much bigger K Street players Google and Facebook with a bipartisan Senate bill unveiled Monday evening that would temporarily exempt publishers from antitrust laws.

The measure — sponsored by Louisiana Republican John Kennedy and Minnesota Democrat Amy Klobuchar — would free up news publishers to jointly bargain with big technology companies in a quest for a bigger slice of digital revenue. It’s the companion to a House bill that Rhode Island Democrat David Cicilline and Georgia Republican Doug Collins introduced this spring.

“At the heart of this bill is helping newspapers survive amid shrinking circulations and massive layoffs,” Kennedy said in a statement. “Google and Facebook now control the news kingdom. They’ve pitted themselves against newspapers in a David-and-Goliath battle in which newspapers don’t have a stone to throw much less a slingshot to put it in. The readers are the true losers as newsrooms empty out across this country. Google and Facebook aren’t just companies. They’re countries. We can’t allow them to bully newspapers out of business.”

Klobuchar added that “without honest and trusted journalists reporting around the world and here at home, what is out of sight truly becomes out of mind — but we’re seeing more and more independent and local news outlets close as ‘fake news’ rises. It’s more important than ever that we protect the free press and establish an even playing field for negotiation with online platforms. Our bipartisan legislation will improve the quality and accessibility of reporting and ensure that journalists are able to continue their critical work.”

Though the news publishers lobby faces major hurdles to turning the legislation into law, the effort is part of a larger campaign to make the group, known until 2016 as the Newspaper Association of America, relevant in an age when most people get their news on screens, not on newsprint.

David Chavern, a longtime K Street insider formerly with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, took over the group in late 2015 and has set about a transformation.

“I have worked hard to basically change everything about the organization that can be changed and to reorient it to really try to fight for a digital future for news publishing,” Chavern said. “We’re going to need a better deal from the platforms if we hope to survive.”

The platforms are primarily Google, Facebook and other big technology companies.

If lobbying revenue is any indication, it’s an unfair fight.

The News Media Alliance reported spending about $385,000 on federal lobbying during the first three months of this year, while Google and Facebook both disclosed shelling out nearly $3.4 million in the same period. In all of last year, the alliance spent $1.8 million on federal lobbying, according to congressional lobbying disclosures. Google reported $21.2 million for 2018, while Facebook dished out $12.6 million.

A Google spokeswoman declined comment. A Facebook spokesman did not provide comment.

But a blog post by the Computer and Communications Industry Association stated in response to the idea: “Antitrust exemptions are rarely granted because consumers lose when competitors collude.”

The CCIA added in its post that while the News Media Alliance “argues that leading tech services are unfairly competing as a ‘duopoly,’ ... experts at the Technology Policy Institute and The Adam Smith Institute, among others, have argued newspaper publishers must adapt to changing markets, not collude.”

Chavern said his team circulated draft legislation in the last Congress, making a case for legislative intervention. While the government can’t regulate the news media, he said, big tech companies somewhat do by controlling the distribution, the ad revenue and data on readers.

Michael Klingensmith, publisher and CEO of the Star Tribune Media Co. in Minneapolis, said he’s been involved in the association for 10 years and credits Chavern with bringing together a disparate collection of news executives.

“We really have sort of coalesced around this issue of being able to more effectively deal with the big platform companies like Google and Facebook,” he said. “It’s something we all have in common.”

The House and Senate legislation would give news publishers a temporary 48-month reprieve from existing antitrust laws, allowing them to band together to negotiate.

“We’ll take what we can get,” Klingensmith said, adding it should be long enough to make a difference.

Chavern, who said four years should be long enough to build a longer-term and sustainable business of online news, expects to testify at a forthcoming hearing in the House Judiciary panel’s Subcommittee on Antitrust, Commercial and Administrative Law, which Cicilline chairs.

“This bill will provide a much-needed lifeline to local publishers who have been crushed by Google and Facebook,” Cicilline said about his bill in a news release.

As for the News Media Alliance, Chavern said that in addition to changing its name, he’s also upped the focus on lobbying and advocacy. The alliance also launched a political action committee, which donated less than $1,000 in the 2018 election cycle to Collins, a sponsor of the House measure, according to federal election records.

The alliance’s revenue has declined in recent years to $7.3 million, according to the group’s 2017 IRS Form 990, from $8.4 million in its 2015 Form 990. But its total assets were up to $22.5 million in the 2017 disclosure from about $20.7 million in 2015 one.

“We’ve become much sharper edged,” Chavern said.

That’s not unique to the news lobby, either. The trade association sector itself is in the throes of disruption as members flee and groups consolidate.

“The News Media Alliance as a trade association is no different than any other trade association in Washington, in 2019,” K Street headhunter Ivan Adler said. “They must focus on bringing value to their members, otherwise they will become irrelevant.”

CQ Roll Call is not a member of the News Media Alliance.

urn:contentItem:5W8N-G341-JCF0-8180-00000-00News Media Alliance pushes for new Senate antitrust bill2019-06-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:08ZLexisNexisNews Media Alliance pushes for new Senate antitrust bill

The News Media Alliance is scoring some legislative points against the much bigger K Street players Google and Facebook with a bipartisan Senate bill unveiled Monday evening that would temporarily exempt publishers from antitrust laws.

The measure -- sponsored by Sens. John Kennedy, R-La., and Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn. -- would free up news publishers to jointly bargain with big technology companies in a quest for a bigger slice of digital revenue. It's the companion to a House bill that Reps. David Cicilline, D-R.I., and Doug Collins, R-Ga., introduced this spring.

"At the heart of this bill is helping newspapers survive amid shrinking circulations and massive layoffs," Kennedy said in a statement. "Google and Facebook now control the news kingdom. They've pitted themselves against newspapers in a David-and-Goliath battle in which newspapers don't have a stone to throw much less a slingshot to put it in. The readers are the true losers as newsrooms empty out across this country. Google and Facebook aren't just companies. They're countries. We can't allow them to bully newspapers out of business."

Klobuchar added that "Without honest and trusted journalists reporting around the world and here at home, what is out of sight truly becomes out of mind -- but we're seeing more and more independent and local news outlets close as 'fake news' rises. It's more important than ever that we protect the free press and establish an even playing field for negotiation with online platforms. Our bipartisan legislation will improve the quality and accessibility of reporting and ensure that journalists are able to continue their critical work."

Though the news publishers lobby faces major hurdles to turning the legislation into law, the effort is part of a larger campaign to make the group, known until 2016 as the Newspaper Association of America, relevant in an age where most people get their news on screens, not on newsprint.

David Chavern, a longtime K Street insider formerly with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, took over the group in late 2015 and has set about a transformation.

"I have worked hard to basically change everything about the organization that can be changed and to reorient it to really try to fight for a digital future for news publishing," Chavern said. "We're going to need a better deal from the platforms if we hope to survive."

The platforms are primarily Google, Facebook and other big technology companies.

If lobbying revenue is any indication, it's an unfair fight.

The News Media Alliance reported spending about $385,000 on federal lobbying during the first three months of this year, while Google and Facebook both disclosed shelling out nearly $3.4 million in the same period. In all of last year, the alliance spent $1.8 million on federal lobbying, according to congressional lobbying disclosures. Google reported $21.2 million for 2018, while Facebook dished out $12.6 million.

A Google spokeswoman declined comment. A Facebook spokesman did not provide comment.

But a blog post by the Computer and Communications Industry Association stated in response to the idea: "Antitrust exemptions are rarely granted because consumers lose when competitors collude." The CCIA added in its post that while the News Media Alliance "argues that leading tech services are unfairly competing as a 'duopoly,'" that "experts at the Technology Policy Institute and The Adam Smith Institute, among others, have argued newspaper publishers must adapt to changing markets, not collude."

Chavern says his team circulated draft legislation in the last Congress, making a case for legislative intervention. While the government can't regulate the news media, he argues, big tech companies sort of do by controlling the distribution, the ad revenue, and data on readers.

Michael Klingensmith, publisher and CEO of the Star Tribune Media Co. in Minneapolis, says he's been involved in the association for 10 years and credits Chavern for bringing together a disparate collection of news executives.

"We really have sort of coalesced around this issue of being able to more effectively deal with the big platform companies like Google and Facebook," he said. "It's something we all have in common."

The House and Senate legislation would give news publishers a temporary 48-month reprieve from existing antitrust laws, allowing them to band together to negotiate.

"We'll take what we can get," Klingensmith said, adding it should be long enough to make a difference.

Chavern, who says four years should be long enough to build a longer-term and sustainable business of online news, expects to testify at a forthcoming hearing in the House Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on Antitrust, Commercial and Administrative Law, which Cicilline chairs.

"This bill will provide a much-needed lifeline to local publishers who have been crushed by Google and Facebook," Cicilline said about his bill in a news release.

As for the News Media Alliance, Chavern says that in addition to changing its name, he's also upped the focus on lobbying and advocacy. The alliance also launched a political action committee, which donated less than $1,000 in the 2017-2018 election cycle to Collins, a sponsor of the House measure, according to federal election records.

The alliance's revenue has declined in recent years to $7.3 million, according to the group's 2017 IRS form 990, from $8.4 million in its 2015 form 990. But its total assets were up to $22.5 million in the 2017 disclosure from about $20.7 million in 2015 one.

"We've become much sharper edged," Chavern said.

That's not unique to the news lobby, either. The trade association sector itself is in the throes of disruption as members flee and groups consolidate.

"The News Media Alliance as a trade association is no different than any other trade association in Washington, in 2019," says K Street headhunter Ivan Adler. "They must focus on bringing value to their members, otherwise they will become irrelevant."

CQ Roll Call is not a member of the News Media Alliance.

urn:contentItem:5X94-CD51-JBHT-D2J6-00000-00News Media Alliance pushes for new Senate antitrust bill2019-06-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:08ZLexisNexisNews Media Alliance pushes for new Senate antitrust billKate AckleyCQ-Roll CallMissoula, Mont.FULL TEXT

WASHINGTON - The News Media Alliance is scoring some legislative points against the much bigger K Street players Google and Facebook with a bipartisan Senate bill unveiled Monday evening that would temporarily exempt publishers from antitrust laws.

The measure - sponsored by Louisiana Republican John Kennedy and Minnesota Democrat Amy Klobuchar - would free up news publishers to jointly bargain with big technology companies in a quest for a bigger slice of digital revenue. It's the companion to a House bill that Rhode Island Democrat David Cicilline and Georgia Republican Doug Collins introduced this spring.

"At the heart of this bill is helping newspapers survive amid shrinking circulations and massive layoffs," Kennedy said in a statement. "Google and Facebook now control the news kingdom. They've pitted themselves against newspapers in a David-and-Goliath battle in which newspapers don't have a stone to throw much less a slingshot to put it in. The readers are the true losers as newsrooms empty out across this country. Google and Facebook aren't just companies. They're countries. We can't allow them to bully newspapers out of business."

Klobuchar added that "without honest and trusted journalists reporting around the world and here at home, what is out of sight truly becomes out of mind - but we're seeing more and more independent and local news outlets close as 'fake news' rises. It's more important than ever that we protect the free press and establish an even playing field for negotiation with online platforms. Our bipartisan legislation will improve the quality and accessibility of reporting and ensure that journalists are able to continue their critical work."

Though the news publishers lobby faces major hurdles to turning the legislation into law, the effort is part of a larger campaign to make the group, known until 2016 as the Newspaper Association of America, relevant in an age when most people get their news on screens, not on newsprint.

David Chavern, a longtime K Street insider formerly with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, took over the group in late 2015 and has set about a transformation.

"I have worked hard to basically change everything about the organization that can be changed and to reorient it to really try to fight for a digital future for news publishing," Chavern said. "We're going to need a better deal from the platforms if we hope to survive."

The platforms are primarily Google, Facebook and other big technology companies.

If lobbying revenue is any indication, it's an unfair fight.

The News Media Alliance reported spending about $385,000 on federal lobbying during the first three months of this year, while Google and Facebook both disclosed shelling out nearly $3.4 million in the same period. In all of last year, the alliance spent $1.8 million on federal lobbying, according to congressional lobbying disclosures. Google reported $21.2 million for 2018, while Facebook dished out $12.6 million.

A Google spokeswoman declined comment. A Facebook spokesman did not provide comment.

But a blog post by the Computer and Communications Industry Association stated in response to the idea: "Antitrust exemptions are rarely granted because consumers lose when competitors collude." The CCIA added in its post that while the News Media Alliance "argues that leading tech services are unfairly competing as a 'duopoly,' ... experts at the Technology Policy Institute and The Adam Smith Institute, among others, have argued newspaper publishers must adapt to changing markets, not collude."

Chavern said his team circulated draft legislation in the last Congress, making a case for legislative intervention. While the government can't regulate the news media, he said, big tech companies somewhat do by controlling the distribution, the ad revenue and data on readers.

Michael Klingensmith, publisher and CEO of the Star Tribune Media Co. in Minneapolis, said he's been involved in the association for 10 years and credits Chavern with bringing together a disparate collection of news executives.

"We really have sort of coalesced around this issue of being able to more effectively deal with the big platform companies like Google and Facebook," he said. "It's something we all have in common."

"We'll take what we can get," Klingensmith said, adding it should be long enough to make a difference.

Chavern, who said four years should be long enough to build a longer-term and sustainable business of online news, expects to testify at a forthcoming hearing in the House Judiciary panel's Subcommittee on Antitrust, Commercial and Administrative Law, which Cicilline chairs.

"This bill will provide a much-needed lifeline to local publishers who have been crushed by Google and Facebook," Cicilline said about his bill in a news release.

As for the News Media Alliance, Chavern said that in addition to changing its name, he's also upped the focus on lobbying and advocacy. The alliance also launched a political action committee, which donated less than $1,000 in the 2018 election cycle to Collins, a sponsor of the House measure, according to federal election records.

The alliance's revenue has declined in recent years to $7.3 million, according to the group's 2017 IRS Form 990, from $8.4 million in its 2015 Form 990. But its total assets were up to $22.5 million in the 2017 disclosure from about $20.7 million in 2015 one.

"We've become much sharper edged," Chavern said.

That's not unique to the news lobby, either. The trade association sector itself is in the throes of disruption as members flee and groups consolidate.

"The News Media Alliance as a trade association is no different than any other trade association in Washington, in 2019," K Street headhunter Ivan Adler said. "They must focus on bringing value to their members, otherwise they will become irrelevant."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5V5N-5VS1-JC3V-63HC-00000-00News Media Pushing Back on Google Opposition to EU Copyright Changes2019-01-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:08ZLexisNexisNews Media Pushing Back on Google Opposition to EU Copyright Changes

A lot is at stake for Internet platforms and publishers in Europe, where an extension of copyright law is being considered.

There's a new fight brewing between the news media and Google.

The News Media Alliance, a trade association that includes the likes of Hearst, Dow Jones and the New York Times, along with thousands of other news publishers, is pushing back hard against Google's "lobbying" against proposed changes to copyright laws in the European Union aimed at getting some protective copyright powers in the hands of publishers that now largely distribute their content over the Internet.

NMA said Google is basically using "scare tactics in order to sway public opinion" - it's claiming online content will become limited if it has to pay for any content it hosts, that traffic will be reduced mainly for smaller publishers - when what's at issue is "securing a basic right for publishers to protect their original content."

Specifically, its being proposed that the EU Copyright Directive enacted in 2001 be expanded to give publishers of all sorts copyright power over "online uses of their press publications by information society service providers." So, platforms like Google and Facebook, which thrive on traffic (and revenue from ad sales based on traffic) generated by content they do not create, would be open to legal liability if they don't have some kind of authorization to use the content.  

Google is positioning the possible changes, set to be enacted this year, as little more than an attempt by the EU to "limit the variety of content" it, and its affiliate YouTube, feature, which would in turn adversely affect consumers and content creators. It's even dubbed its campaign against the updated directive "Together for Copyright" with a theme of an open Internet being a better Internet, akin to its corporate mission statement.

"Imagine if you couldn't watch the videos you love," Google wrote, "Imagine if you couldn't find your favorite local news or special interest content."

"The European Parliament's proposed version of the legislation would require search services to put licenses in place that may force them to start choosing which content to include and which to exclude," it added.

Meanwhile, NMA argued that the proposal will "actually increase the publishers' options when making decisions on how to make their content available online, and they would not be required to charge for their content."

Google went on to note 35 million YouTube channels in the EU "may be affected" by the rule change and that more than 80,000 news publishers around the world get traffic through its search engine, which it said equals about 10 billion visits a month resulting in a rough average of 4 cents to 8 cents per visit.

Google's math stopped there, but taking the low end of the average, that's equal to about 400 million euros. Split that evenly between 80,000 news publishers and they get roughly 5,000 euros for the millions of visits they receive every month. Meanwhile, Google is pulling tens of billion of dollars in revenue, driven almost entirely by advertising based on traffic, each quarter.  

Needless to say, NMA isn't having the company's argument.

"Currently, online platforms such as Google and other corporate businesses can use - and make money from - publishers' online news content every day, paying the publishers nothing," NMA wrote. "For obvious reasons, Google would prefer to keep the status quo and go on using publishers' content for free, but this is not a fair and equitable arrangement for news publishers, many of whom are already struggling with decreased revenues from shifting preferences away from print and advertisers electing to give their ad dollars to the platforms.

"Without fair compensation for commercial use of news content, the financial futures of free and independent news organizations and journalists are at risk," the NMA continued. "Google asks you to imagine if you couldn't find your favorite local news or special interest content. Supporting a strong publishers' right is the best way to ensure you can continue to find it."

For More, See:

Media People: Richard Gingras of Google News

What to Watch: Regulation of Big Tech

Instagram Swipe 'Test': Sneak Peak or One Off?
